Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Computational Screening of Metal Alloys for the Electrochemical Reduction of CO2 to Fuels
Award.AbstractNarration:
Discovering an efficient and selective catalyst for CO2 reduction to fuels is an important step towards sustainable energy production, for the benefits of reinforcing national energy independence and allowing the integration of renewable energy sources to current energy infrastructures. In this study rigorous quantum mechanical calculations will be employed to screen for CO2 reduction catalysts in metal alloys. The research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Haibin Su, a noted expert on modeling chemical reactions in nanoparticle systems, at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.

Currently, copper is the only known electrocatalyst that reduce CO2 beyond 2-electron reduction. However, neither efficiency nor selectivity are sufficient for industrial scale application. In this study, CO2 reduction materials will be screened under specific pH and applied potentials. Formate forming metals will be chosen as the host substrate and one of the surface metal atom will be replaced by a different metal atom to form single-atom alloys (SAA) for targeted reactions. For the purpose of high efficiency, moderately applied potentials are required. At such a potential range, formate forming metals will not produce undesired by-products like hydrogen gas and CO, thus providing adsorbed hydrogen atoms to activate CO2. By using different transition metals at the single metal atom site, the activity as well as the selectivity towards CO2 reduction can be optimized. To determine the stability of the metal alloy, metal-metal interactions will be evaluated in collaboration with Dr. Su.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we performed quantum chemical calculations to screen for potential catalysts to electrochemically reduce CO2 to useful fuels and products. However, the electrochemical process of CO2 reduction is complex and involves multiple adsorbed species and compounds. In order to find the most promising catalysts, we first developed a multistep approach to rigorously select the candidate catalysts by eliminating the undesirable properties. Using this as a guide, we calculated relevant chemical properties and found many catalysts that are potentially suitable for reducing CO2.

 

Intellectually, our research has demonstrated that a complex problem like catalysts screening for CO2 reduction can still be done rigorously by considering the intrinsic reaction processes. Such computation provides crucial theoretical insights for experimentalists to synthesize high performance materials that could lead to efficient catalysts. 

 

In the broader picture, developing an efficient CO2 reduction catalyst will help advance the technologies in solving environmental and energy-related issues. As the production of renewable energy is increasing every year, CO2 reduction is a promising process to store the energy into carbon form that can be easily integrated into the traditional chemical infrastructure and transportation system and can potentially reduce the dependence on foreign energy sources. At the same time, removing CO2 from the atmosphere completes the carbon cycle to consume energy in a a sustainable and renewable way. 

 


Last Modified: 08/03/2018
Modified by: Yufeng Huang
